summary.text: Scientific investigations follow systematic approaches: experiments (controlled variables), fieldwork (natural settings), classification (organizing by characteristics), modeling (simplified representations), or product development (engineering solutions).

importance.text: Different questions need different methods. Can't do controlled experiments on stars. Can't classify what doesn't exist. Method matches question.

explanations.text: Because reality is complex. Some things we control (labs), some we observe (field), some we simulate (models). Each reveals different truths.
Control vs authenticity trade-off. Labs control variables but lose real-world complexity. Field studies are authentic but messy. Choose wisely.
It's epistemology—how we know what we know. Different methods produce different types of knowledge. Triangulation across methods strengthens conclusions.
Match method to question. No universal best.

questions.text: Which methodology is most appropriate for investigating 'How does wing shape affect seed dispersal distance?'

options.explanation: Classification organizes existing things. This investigates cause-effect relationships.
Correct! Vary wing shape (independent), measure distance (dependent), control other factors.
This studies natural phenomena, not creating new products.
Field observation can't isolate wing shape effects from other variables.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Controlled experiments isolate variables to establish causation.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what you're trying to prove—causation needs controlled variables.
feedback.explanation: Testing how ONE factor (wing shape) affects another (distance) requires controlling all other variables. That's experimentation.

questions.text: Fieldwork always produces more valid results than laboratory experiments because it studies real-world conditions.

modelAnswer.text: False. Neither method is inherently more valid—they serve different purposes. Laboratory experiments excel at establishing causation through variable control but may lack ecological validity. Fieldwork captures real-world complexity and interactions but can't isolate variables. Validity depends on matching method to research question. Studying chemical reaction rates? Lab wins. Studying ecosystem interactions? Field wins.

questions.text: A student wants to investigate 'What factors affect the stability of different church buttress designs?' Identify the most appropriate methodology and explain why, including what data would be collected.

steps.text: Most appropriate: Modeling (physical scale models or computer simulation)
Reasoning: Can't experiment on real churches (ethics/practicality), need to test multiple designs systematically
Data collected: Maximum load before failure, deflection under standard loads, stress distribution patterns
Variables: Buttress angle, thickness, material, height

solution.finalAnswer: Modeling allows systematic testing of design variables while avoiding destruction of actual buildings

summary.text: Independent variable = what you change. Dependent variable = what you measure. Controlled variables = what you keep constant. Uncontrolled = confounding factors that mess everything up.

importance.text: Control isolates causation. Without it, you don't know what caused what. Every uncontrolled variable is a rival explanation for your results.

explanations.text: Because correlation isn't causation. Ice cream sales correlate with drownings (both increase in summer). Control reveals true causes.
It's the ceteris paribus principle—'all else equal.' Change one thing at a time or you'll never untangle effects.
Reality is multicausal. Everything affects everything. Control artificially simplifies to make causation visible. It's reductionist but necessary.
One variable changes. Rest stay put. Causation emerges.

questions.text: In an investigation of 'How does ramp angle affect the speed of a marble?', what is the dependent variable?

options.explanation: This is what you change (independent variable), not what you measure.
This should be controlled (kept constant) across trials.
Correct! Speed is what you measure in response to changing angle.
Another controlled variable—keep it constant to isolate angle effects.

feedback.correct: Exactly! The dependent variable depends on what you change.
feedback.incorrect: What are you measuring? That's your dependent variable.
feedback.explanation: Dependent = depends on the independent. You change angle, then measure resulting speed.

questions.text: A student investigates whether music affects plant growth but doesn't control light exposure. Explain why this compromises the investigation.

steps.text: Light is a major factor in plant growth (photosynthesis)
Without controlling light, any growth differences could be due to:
1. Music effects (intended) OR 2. Light differences (confounding)
Cannot determine causation—rival explanation exists

solution.finalAnswer: Uncontrolled light exposure creates a confounding variable that could explain results instead of music

questions.text: Investigating multiple independent variables simultaneously in one experiment always produces more efficient research.

modelAnswer.text: False. While factorial designs can test multiple variables and their interactions efficiently, they complicate analysis and interpretation. Simple designs with one independent variable clearly show cause-effect relationships. Multiple variables create interaction effects that can mask or confound main effects. Start simple, establish individual effects, then explore interactions. Efficiency isn't just about quantity—it's about clarity of conclusions.

summary.text: Accuracy = how close to true value. Precision = how close measurements are to each other. Validity = does it measure what it claims? Different flaws, different fixes.

importance.text: Bad data = bad conclusions. You can be precisely wrong (systematic error) or imprecisely right (random error). Both undermine trust.

explanations.text: Because measurement isn't perfect. Instruments drift, humans err, conditions vary. Understanding error types helps fix them.
It's signal vs noise. True value is signal, variation is noise. Accuracy failures add bias (shifts signal), precision failures add static (random noise).
Measurement is a sampling problem. We sample reality imperfectly. Systematic sampling errors (accuracy) vs random sampling errors (precision).
Accurate = correct average. Precise = tight grouping. Need both.

questions.text: Darts clustered together but far from bullseye represent measurements that are:

options.explanation: Opposite—clustering shows precision, missing target shows poor accuracy.
Correct! Tight grouping (precise) but wrong location (inaccurate).
Can't be accurate if far from target (true value).
Clustering indicates precision, even if inaccurate.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Classic case of systematic error—consistent but wrong.
feedback.incorrect: Clustered = precise. Far from target = inaccurate.
feedback.explanation: Like a miscalibrated instrument—gives consistent (precise) readings that are all wrong by the same amount (inaccurate).

questions.text: Which action would most likely improve accuracy but not precision?

options.explanation: More measurements might reveal precision issues but don't fix systematic errors.
Correct! Calibration fixes systematic bias (accuracy) without affecting random spread (precision).
Resolution affects smallest detectable difference, not systematic bias.
This reduces random variations, improving precision more than accuracy.

feedback.correct: Exactly! Calibration corrects systematic offset without changing measurement spread.
feedback.incorrect: Think about what causes inaccuracy—systematic bias needs systematic fix.
feedback.explanation: Calibration adjusts for known bias. Like zeroing a scale—shifts all readings toward true value without changing their spread.

questions.text: A reaction time test measures how quickly students press a button after seeing a light. Explain how this test could be reliable but not valid for measuring alertness.

expectedAnswer.value: Measures motor response consistently, not mental alertness

steps.text: Reliability: Test gives consistent results for same person (precise/repeatable)
Validity issue: Measures motor speed + visual processing, not just alertness
Someone with fast reflexes scores well regardless of alertness level
Confounds: caffeine affects motor speed, practice improves times

solution.finalAnswer: Test reliably measures reaction time but this doesn't validly represent alertness—too many other factors influence the measurement

summary.text: Every measurement has uncertainty. Absolute uncertainty = ±half smallest scale division. Percentage uncertainty = (absolute/measurement) × 100%. Uncertainties propagate through calculations.

importance.text: Uncertainty quantifies doubt. Without it, you claim false precision. '5.2 cm' vs '5.2 ± 0.1 cm' sends different messages about measurement quality.

explanations.text: Because perfect measurement is impossible. Every instrument has limits. Honesty about uncertainty = scientific integrity.
It's information theory. More precision requires more information. Physical limits (quantum uncertainty, thermal noise) set fundamental boundaries.
Measurement extracts finite information from infinite reality. Uncertainty quantifies information loss. It's epistemological humility.
Can't know perfectly. Uncertainty admits this.

questions.text: A ruler with 1 mm divisions measures a length as 45 mm. What is the absolute uncertainty?

options.explanation: This is the full division. Uncertainty is half the smallest division.
Correct! Uncertainty = ± (smallest division / 2) = ± 0.5 mm
Too precise—can't be more certain than half the scale division.
Too large—this assumes very poor reading ability.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Standard uncertainty is half the resolution.
feedback.explanation: With 1 mm marks, you can estimate to nearest 0.5 mm. Hence ± 0.5 mm uncertainty.

questions.text: A digital scale reads 2.45 g with ± 0.01 g uncertainty. Calculate the percentage uncertainty.

steps.text: Given: measurement = 2.45 g, absolute uncertainty = ± 0.01 g
Percentage uncertainty = (absolute uncertainty / measurement) × 100%

questions.text: When multiplying two measurements, their percentage uncertainties add together.

modelAnswer.text: True. For multiplication and division, percentage uncertainties add (approximately, for small uncertainties). If A = 10 ± 5% and B = 20 ± 3%, then A×B has uncertainty ≈ 5% + 3% = 8%. This comes from calculus—taking partial derivatives shows relative errors combine additively for products. For addition/subtraction, absolute uncertainties add in quadrature.

summary.text: Safety: identify hazards, assess risks, implement controls. Ethics: informed consent, minimize harm, respect subjects. Both are non-negotiable in scientific work.

importance.text: Science without ethics is dangerous. Safety protects researchers. Ethics protects subjects and society. Both preserve science's social license.

explanations.text: Because science affects real people. Bad safety hurts researchers. Bad ethics hurts subjects and public trust. Both undermine science's purpose.
Power requires responsibility. Scientific knowledge is power. Ethics ensures power serves humanity, not harms it. Safety is ethics applied to researchers.
It's the social contract. Society funds science expecting benefit, not harm. Ethics and safety uphold this contract. Breach it, lose support.
First, do no harm. Then, discover.

questions.text: What is the correct hierarchy of hazard controls from most to least effective?

options.explanation: Backwards—PPE is last resort, not first line of defense.

options.text: Elimination, substitution, engineering controls, admin controls, PPE
options.explanation: Correct! Remove hazard first, protect person last.
Wrong order—always try to eliminate hazard before managing it.
Inverted—procedures are weaker than physical changes.

feedback.correct: Perfect! The hierarchy prioritizes removing danger over protecting from it.
feedback.incorrect: Think: eliminate danger > reduce danger > protect from danger.
feedback.explanation: Best to worst: Eliminate (remove hazard), Substitute (safer alternative), Engineer (barriers), Administrative (procedures), PPE (last resort).

questions.text: Recording video of students during an experiment for analysis requires informed consent, even if faces aren't shown.

modelAnswer.text: True. Any recording of human subjects requires informed consent, regardless of identifiability. Even anonymized data involves human participants who have rights to know how their data will be used, stored, and shared. Consent must be voluntary, informed (understanding purpose and risks), and documented. This respects autonomy and privacy—fundamental ethical principles in research.

questions.text: Students plan to test projectile motion by launching marbles across the classroom. Identify three safety hazards and propose controls for each.

expectedAnswer.value: Eye injury, trip hazards, property damage with specific controls

steps.text: Hazard 1: Eye injury from projectiles
equations: Control: Safety goggles for all, defined firing zone, barriers

steps.text: Hazard 2: Trip hazards from equipment
equations: Control: Designated launch area, clear walkways, equipment storage

steps.text: Hazard 3: Property damage (windows, equipment)
equations: Control: Soft backstop, restricted launch angles, lower power

solution.finalAnswer: Multiple hazards require layered controls—PPE, spatial management, and operational limits

concepts.title: Aims, Hypotheses, Models, Theories, and Laws

summary.text: Aim = what you want to find out. Hypothesis = testable prediction. Model = simplified representation. Theory = well-supported explanation. Law = mathematical relationship. Different tools for different jobs.

importance.text: Precision in language = precision in thought. Calling a hypothesis a theory weakens both. Each term represents different confidence levels in scientific knowledge.

explanations.text: Because science builds knowledge hierarchically. Observations → hypotheses → models → theories → laws. Each level requires more evidence.
It's about epistemic confidence. Hypothesis = 'maybe.' Theory = 'almost certainly.' Law = 'mathematically true within domain.' Language reflects certainty.
Science is provisional. Even laws have limits (Newton works until near light speed). Terms acknowledge this—nothing is absolute truth, just current best understanding.
Words match confidence. Hypothesis hopes. Theory explains. Law calculates.

questions.text: Which statement represents a proper scientific hypothesis?

options.text: Plants are important for the environment
options.explanation: Too vague and not testable. What does 'important' mean? How measured?

options.text: If temperature increases, then gas pressure will increase
options.explanation: Correct! Clear if-then structure, testable, measurable variables.
This is a question, not a hypothesis. Hypotheses are statements.
Not testable in practice—can't check everywhere. Too broad.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Clear variables and testable prediction.
feedback.incorrect: Hypotheses must be testable if-then statements.
feedback.explanation: Good hypotheses predict relationships between measurable variables. If X changes, then Y will change in this specific way.

questions.text: What distinguishes a scientific law from a theory?

options.text: Laws are proven true, theories are still uncertain
options.explanation: Nothing in science is 'proven true'—all knowledge is provisional.

options.text: Laws describe what happens, theories explain why
options.explanation: Correct! Laws are mathematical descriptions, theories provide mechanisms.
Age doesn't determine classification. Some theories predate laws.
They serve different purposes—one doesn't evolve into the other.

feedback.correct: Excellent! Laws = mathematical relationships, theories = explanatory frameworks.
feedback.incorrect: Think about what each provides: description vs explanation.
feedback.explanation: Ohm's Law tells us V=IR (what happens). Electron theory explains why (electron flow through resistance causes voltage drop).

questions.text: The particle model treats gas molecules as point masses with no volume. Explain why this model works well at low pressure but fails at high pressure.

expectedAnswer.value: Molecular volume becomes significant fraction of container volume

steps.text: At low pressure: molecules far apart, actual volume negligible compared to container
Point mass assumption valid—molecule size doesn't matter
At high pressure: molecules crowded, their volume significant
Real volume reduces free space, increases collisions beyond point-mass predictions

solution.finalAnswer: Model assumptions break down when molecular volume becomes non-negligible fraction of total volume

summary.text: Primary data = data you collect yourself. Direct from source, tailored to your question. Includes raw measurements, observations, survey responses. You control quality but bear responsibility.

importance.text: Primary data fits your exact needs. No wondering about methods or biases—you know because you did it. But with great power comes great protocol.

explanations.text: Because secondhand data might not match your needs. Different question = different data requirements. Primary collection ensures fit.
It's about control and specificity. You control variables, timing, precision. Secondary data comes with others' choices baked in.
Data has context. Primary collection preserves full context—you know all conditions. Secondary data loses context in translation.
Your question, your data. Perfect fit.

questions.text: Which represents primary data in a study on local water quality?

options.text: Government water quality reports from last year
options.explanation: Secondary—someone else collected this data.

options.text: pH measurements you take from local streams
options.explanation: Correct! You personally collect these measurements.

options.text: Published research on water quality methods
options.explanation: Secondary—this is others' work, not your data.

options.text: Online database of historical water data
options.explanation: Secondary—pre-existing data collected by others.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Primary = you collect it yourself.
feedback.incorrect: Primary data comes from your own direct collection.
feedback.explanation: If you personally measure, observe, or record it, it's primary. If someone else did, it's secondary.

questions.text: Collecting primary data eliminates all forms of bias in research.

modelAnswer.text: False. Primary data collection can introduce its own biases: sampling bias (who/what you measure), measurement bias (how you measure), observer bias (expectations affecting observations), and temporal bias (when you measure). The advantage of primary data is knowing these potential biases and controlling for them, not eliminating them entirely. Good experimental design minimizes but never eliminates bias.

questions.text: A student investigates 'How do different surfaces affect ball bounce height?' Identify one qualitative and one quantitative primary data type to collect.

expectedAnswer.value: Quantitative: bounce height; Qualitative: surface texture description

steps.text: Quantitative (numerical): Bounce height in cm, number of bounces, time between bounces
Qualitative (descriptive): Surface texture (rough/smooth), bounce sound, deformation observations
Both types provide complementary information

solution.finalAnswer: Quantitative: measured bounce heights; Qualitative: surface characteristic descriptions

summary.text: Raw data is chaos. Organization reveals patterns: tables show structure, graphs show trends, statistics show significance. Transform numbers into understanding.

importance.text: Data doesn't speak for itself. Analysis makes it talk. Bad analysis makes it lie. Good analysis extracts truth without adding fiction.

explanations.text: Because patterns hide in noise. Human brains can't process raw numbers efficiently. Visual and statistical tools reveal what matters.
It's data compression. Analysis extracts essential information, discards noise. Like jpeg for numbers—keep what matters, lose what doesn't.
Information theory: data has entropy. Analysis reduces entropy, increases information density. We're mining meaning from measurement.
Numbers → patterns → meaning.

questions.text: Which graph type best shows the relationship between continuous variables like temperature and pressure?

options.explanation: Pie charts show parts of a whole, not relationships between variables.
Bar graphs better suit categorical data, not continuous relationships.

options.text: Scatter plot with line of best fit
options.explanation: Correct! Shows individual points and overall trend for continuous data.
Histograms show distribution of one variable, not relationships between two.

feedback.correct: Excellent! Scatter plots reveal relationships and trends between continuous variables.
feedback.incorrect: Consider what each graph type shows best.
feedback.explanation: Scatter plots display x-y pairs as points. Patterns (linear, curved, none) show relationships. Best fit lines quantify trends.

questions.text: Outliers should always be removed from data sets to improve accuracy.

modelAnswer.text: False. Outliers should be investigated, not automatically removed. They might represent: real extreme values (keep them), measurement errors (remove/remeasure), or interesting phenomena worth studying. Removing without investigation loses potentially important information. Document decisions: if removed, explain why; if kept, note their presence. Statistical tests can identify outliers, but judgment determines their fate.

questions.text: Data shows period squared (T²) vs length (L) for a pendulum gives a straight line through origin. What does this reveal about the relationship between period and length?

expectedAnswer.value: Period proportional to square root of length

steps.text: Straight line through origin means: T² ∝ L
Therefore: T² = kL (where k is constant slope)
Taking square root: T = √(kL) = √k × √L
So: T ∝ √L (period proportional to square root of length)

solution.finalAnswer: Linear T² vs L graph reveals T ∝ √L relationship

summary.text: Random error = unpredictable scatter. Systematic error = consistent bias. Human error = mistakes (redo!). Every method has limits. Acknowledging limitations = good science.

importance.text: Error isn't failure—it's information. Understanding error types helps fix them. Stating limitations shows scientific maturity, not weakness.

explanations.text: Because perfection is impossible. Every measurement, method, and model has limits. Pretending otherwise is dishonest and dangerous.
It's signal processing. Random error is noise (reduce by averaging). Systematic error is bias (fix by calibration). Different problems, different solutions.
Gödel's incompleteness applies. No system can fully describe itself. Science studying nature is nature studying itself—fundamental limits exist.
Perfect knowledge impossible. Error quantifies ignorance.

questions.text: A balance always reads 0.2 g too high. This represents:

options.explanation: Random varies unpredictably. This is consistent.
Correct! Consistent bias in one direction = systematic.
Human error is mistakes, not consistent instrument bias.
Consistency doesn't eliminate error—measurements still wrong.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Systematic = consistent bias in measurements.
feedback.explanation: Systematic errors shift all measurements by same amount. Fix by calibration or mathematical correction.

questions.text: Which strategy best reduces random error?

options.explanation: Price doesn't guarantee less random error. Precision matters more.
Correct! Averaging reduces random scatter around true value.
Expertise might reduce mistakes but not inherent random variation.
Calibration fixes systematic error, not random variation.

feedback.correct: Exactly! Random errors cancel out when averaged.
feedback.incorrect: Random means unpredictable—what makes unpredictable variations cancel?
feedback.explanation: Random errors are equally likely positive or negative. Averaging many measurements approaches true value as errors cancel.

questions.text: A student investigates reaction time using a ruler drop test. State two limitations of this method and explain their impact on conclusions.

expectedAnswer.value: Anticipation and limited precision affect validity

steps.text: Limitation 1: Anticipation - subjects might predict release
equations: Impact: Artificially fast times, not true reaction

steps.text: Limitation 2: Ruler precision (~1cm) limits time resolution
equations: Impact: Can't distinguish small reaction time differences

steps.text: Additional: Single stimulus type (visual) doesn't represent all reactions

solution.finalAnswer: Method limitations constrain conclusion validity and generalizability

summary.text: Science progresses by breaking itself. Anomalies accumulate until current models crack. New theories emerge. Rinse, repeat. Progress through destruction.

importance.text: Anomalies drive revolutions. Mercury's orbit broke Newton, birthed Einstein. Ultraviolet catastrophe broke classical physics, birthed quantum. Breaks create breakthroughs.

explanations.text: Because models simplify reality. Eventually, reality's complexity overwhelms simplification. Edge cases multiply until they're not edges anymore.
It's Kuhn's paradigm shifts. Normal science accumulates anomalies. Crisis when anomalies become undeniable. Revolution when new paradigm explains more.
Gödel strikes again. Systems can't prove their own consistency. External evidence (experiments) reveals internal contradictions. Reality judges theory.
Theories die by data. Better theories born.

questions.text: When experimental results consistently contradict established theory, scientists should first:

options.explanation: Too hasty—theories earn trust through past success.
Correct! Verify anomaly before overthrowing theory.
Anti-scientific—evidence matters more than theory comfort.
Fraud! Never manipulate data to fit expectations.

feedback.correct: Exactly! Extraordinary claims need extraordinary evidence.
feedback.incorrect: Consider how to verify anomalies are real.
feedback.explanation: Replicate first—equipment errors and methodological flaws are more common than theory-breaking discoveries. If anomaly persists, then investigate seriously.

questions.text: Scientific revolutions completely discard all aspects of previous theories.

modelAnswer.text: False. New theories typically incorporate successful predictions of old theories as special cases. Einstein didn't discard Newton—relativistic equations reduce to Newtonian at low speeds. Quantum mechanics includes classical mechanics at large scales. Revolutionary theories explain why old theories worked within their domains while extending to new domains. It's expansion, not replacement.

questions.text: The photoelectric effect showed light frequency (not intensity) determines electron ejection energy. Explain why this challenged classical wave theory.

expectedAnswer.value: Wave energy depends on amplitude/intensity, not frequency

steps.text: Classical prediction: Wave energy ∝ amplitude² (intensity)
Higher intensity = more energy = should eject electrons
Observation: Only frequency matters, intensity affects number not energy
Implies energy comes in frequency-dependent packets (photons)

solution.finalAnswer: Frequency dependence implied quantized energy, incompatible with continuous waves

summary.text: Scientific reports follow strict structure: Title, Abstract, Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion, Conclusion, References. Each section has specific purpose. Clarity beats creativity.

importance.text: Reproducibility requires communication. Others must understand exactly what you did. Standard structure helps readers find information quickly.

explanations.text: Because science is communal. Your work builds on others', others build on yours. Clear communication enables this construction.
It's protocol for peer review. Standardized format helps reviewers evaluate efficiently. Deviation frustrates, reducing impact.
Information architecture. Predictable structure reduces cognitive load. Readers know where to look, writers know what goes where.
Same structure everywhere. Find information fast.

questions.text: Which section contains raw data tables and graphs without interpretation?

options.explanation: Introduction provides background and aims, not data.
Methods describe procedures, not results.
Correct! Results present data objectively without interpretation.
Discussion interprets results, doesn't present raw data.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Results show what you found, discussion explains what it means.
feedback.incorrect: Which section presents findings without explaining them?
feedback.explanation: Results section is just facts—data, graphs, observations. Save interpretation for discussion.

questions.text: An abstract should include detailed methodological steps and all data collected.

modelAnswer.text: False. Abstracts are summaries (typically 150-300 words) containing: brief background, aims, key methods (not detailed steps), main results (not all data), and major conclusions. Think elevator pitch, not instruction manual. Readers use abstracts to decide whether to read the full paper. Include enough to understand what was done and found, not enough to replicate.

questions.text: Convert this informal description to proper methods writing: 'We got some pendulums and timed them swinging.'

expectedAnswer.value: Past tense, passive voice, specific details

steps.text: Use past tense and passive voice (standard for methods)
Add specific details: what pendulums, how timed, how many trials

Example revision: 'Simple pendulums of varying lengths (0.20-1.00 m) were constructed using string and metal washers. Period was measured using a digital stopwatch (±0.01 s) for 10 complete oscillations.'

solution.finalAnswer: Pendulums of specified lengths were constructed and their periods were measured using digital timing over multiple oscillations

summary.text: Science speaks precisely. SI units, significant figures, standard symbols, proper citations. Every detail matters. Ambiguity kills reproducibility.

importance.text: Universal language enables global collaboration. '5 meters' means same thing everywhere. '5' alone means nothing. Precision in language reflects precision in thought.

explanations.text: Because ambiguity causes errors. Mars Climate Orbiter crashed from unit confusion. Details matter when stakes are high.
It's standardization for scalability. Common conventions let strangers collaborate. Like programming languages—syntax enables communication.
Language shapes thought (Sapir-Whorf). Precise terminology enforces precise thinking. Sloppy language permits sloppy reasoning.
Same words, same meaning. Global understanding.

questions.text: Which represents correct SI unit usage in a report?

options.explanation: Correct! Proper SI unit with space between number and unit.
Missing space between number and unit—standard requires space.
Use standard symbols (m/s), not full words in measurements.
While mathematically correct, m/s is clearer for reports.

feedback.correct: Perfect! Space between number and unit is standard.
feedback.explanation: Standard format: number [space] unit symbol. So 5 m/s, not 5m/s or 5 meters/second.

questions.text: You measure 2.1 cm and 3.26 cm. Their sum should be reported as:

options.explanation: Too many decimal places—limited by least precise measurement.
Correct! Limited to 1 decimal place (matching 2.1).
Too few significant figures—unnecessarily imprecise.
False precision—can't be more precise than inputs.

feedback.correct: Exactly! Addition/subtraction limited by least precise decimal place.
feedback.incorrect: Consider decimal places in the original measurements.
feedback.explanation: For addition/subtraction, result has same decimal places as least precise input. 2.1 has 1 decimal place, so answer: 5.4

questions.text: Explain why scientific reports require citations and what happens without them.

steps.text: Citations serve multiple purposes:
1. Give credit—acknowledge others' work (ethical requirement)
2. Enable verification—readers can check sources
3. Show foundation—demonstrates knowledge of field
Without citations: plagiarism (theft), unverifiable claims, appears ignorant of field

solution.finalAnswer: Citations give credit and enable verification; absence constitutes plagiarism and prevents fact-checking

summary.text: Data means nothing without theory. Connect observations to physics principles. Show how results support/challenge established concepts. Bridge particular to universal.

importance.text: This transforms school project into real science. Anyone can collect data. Scientists connect data to bigger picture. That's where understanding lives.

explanations.text: Because science seeks general principles, not just specific facts. Your pendulum data should illuminate gravity, not just one string's behavior.
It's induction—from specific observations to general laws. Each experiment is a data point supporting broader theories. Connection validates both.
Knowledge is networked, not isolated. New findings gain meaning through connection to existing knowledge. Isolated facts are trivia; connected facts are understanding.
Data + theory = understanding.

questions.text: A student finds that doubling pendulum length increases period by factor of 1.41. This supports which physics concept?

options.explanation: Energy is conserved, but this doesn't explain the 1.41 factor.
Newton's second law applies but doesn't predict this specific relationship.
Correct! 1.41 ≈ √2, confirming period proportional to √length.
Momentum is conserved but doesn't determine pendulum period.

feedback.correct: Excellent! You connected numerical result to theoretical prediction.
feedback.incorrect: What's 1.41 approximately equal to? Think square roots.
feedback.explanation: 1.41 ≈ √2. When length doubles, period increases by √2, confirming T ∝ √L from pendulum equation.

questions.text: Results that don't match theoretical predictions are failures that should be hidden in reports.

modelAnswer.text: False. Unexpected results are often the most valuable! They might reveal: experimental errors to fix, limitations of theoretical models, or new phenomena to explore. Always report honestly and analyze why results differ from predictions. Consider systematic errors, assumptions in theory, or edge cases. Science progresses through anomalies—hiding them halts progress. Document everything, analyze thoroughly.

questions.text: A projectile motion experiment shows shorter range than predicted. Explain how air resistance connects to the energy concepts from Unit 2.

expectedAnswer.value: Air resistance does negative work, removing mechanical energy

steps.text: Theoretical prediction assumes energy conservation (KE + PE = constant)
Air resistance is non-conservative force doing negative work
W_air = F·d < 0 (force opposes motion)
This work removes mechanical energy, converting to thermal
Less energy available for motion = shorter range

solution.finalAnswer: Air resistance does negative work, converting mechanical energy to thermal, reducing projectile range

summary.text: Logbooks are legal documents. Date every entry, write in pen, cross out mistakes (don't erase), initial changes. Real-time documentation, not later recreation.

importance.text: Logbooks prove what you did when. Patents, priority disputes, and academic integrity depend on contemporaneous records. Memory lies; logbooks don't.

explanations.text: Because science values priority and reproducibility. Who discovered what when? Exactly what was done? Logbooks answer both.
It's legal protection and scientific integrity. Courts accept logbooks as evidence. Journals require them for verification. Trust needs documentation.
Human memory reconstructs rather than records. We unconsciously edit past to match present knowledge. Contemporaneous records preserve actual history.
Write now. Memory lies later.

questions.text: You write the wrong value in your logbook. What should you do?

options.explanation: Never use white-out—it hides original entry.

options.text: Tear out the page and start over
options.explanation: Never remove pages—breaks chronological record.

options.text: Cross out with single line, write correction, initial and date
options.explanation: Correct! Shows both error and correction transparently.
Original should remain readable—single line only.

feedback.incorrect: Logbooks must show all entries, including mistakes.
feedback.explanation: Single line keeps original visible while clearly marking it as error. Initial and date show who made correction when.

questions.text: It's acceptable to write up your logbook from memory the day after an experiment if you remember everything clearly.

modelAnswer.text: False. Logbooks must be contemporaneous—written during or immediately after observations. Memory is unreliable and unconsciously edits. You might remember results that match expectations rather than actual observations. Real-time recording captures surprises, mistakes, and details you'd forget. Legal validity requires contemporaneous documentation. 'The palest ink is better than the best memory.'

questions.text: List three features that make a logbook legally authentic for establishing scientific priority.

expectedAnswer.value: Bound pages, dated entries, permanent ink

steps.text: 1. Bound (not loose-leaf)—prevents page insertion/removal
2. Chronological dated entries—establishes timeline
3. Permanent ink—prevents alteration
